narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned SO MUCH! I learned about histories of queer and trans activism, archiving, state violence, community-building, critical thinking, imagining that a better world is possible

This class taught me to really look at a wide variety of issues from a queer perspective that I had never considered before. As a cis/heterosexual man, I think that this class was an eye opening experience that has made me a more considerate person and has definitely influenced the way I think/act.

This course taught me so much about our society that is often overlooked and rarely spoken about, especially in our Yale bubble.  The focus on queer politics allowed me to explore histories that are often not included in a traditional education.
I learned so much about queer and trans theory, particularly from the perspective of BIPOC. This course impacted my worldviews and outlooks in terms of state power, neoliberalism, necropolitics, etc.

So much knowledge, so much insight. You learn about LGBTQ activisms, clashes within revolutionary organizations, oppression within the oppressed. Just so much. Do you know Marx? Sylvia Rivera? Merle Woo? What about Snorton? Haritaworn? If you said no to any of these, this is the class for you!

I know have a much greater and more detailed understanding of queer politics especially that of queer people of color. This was contextualized by many diverse forms of primary sources. I'm now more cognizant of the lost or hidden histories of many important movements and will more likely question how we archive history, discuss politics and reimagine futures.
I was able to learn a lot about queer and trans history and dived into many different authors that helped me understand important ideas.
i learned so much about reading the archives, critical analyses of queer and trans politics, and different reading and brainstorming techniques.
Professor Ferguson and all of the TFs really taught us authentic history and allowed us to discuss it in a thought provoking and engaged manner.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: strengths: PROF. FERGUSON! the teaching fellows! the assignments were creative and manageable, the reading load was manageable, the energy in class discussions -- everything was just amazing; weaknesses: none

This course was great because Prof. Ferguson genuinely cares about his students. He is intentional about listening to feedback he receives during class and then adjusting the class accordingly. I am thankful for his thoughtfulness.

Strengths- course load was perfect, readings were never too overwhelming and class discussion allowed for in-depth discussions
Literally no weaknesses

The people: All students and teachers were super engaged and brought meaningful contributions to the conversations. Every class was a joy and it was really great to spend a lot of time relating the material to our personal lives. Professor Ferguson is INCREDIBLE. He and the TA's understood how difficult this semester was and gave everyone an "A" about halfway through. This allowed us to really loosen up and bring our best selves to class.

strengths: I loved Professor Ferguson's choice of readings and sources, as well as the seminar structured class. I also loved the different thinking hat exercises he integrates into the class, as it allows us to appreciate the content in a variety of ways. I also loved how this class pushed us to engage with our creative thinking. 
No weaknesses!
Too much reading!

No weaknesses, only strength. Main strength: Professor Ferguson CARES ABOUT YOU. The TAs (at least this year) CARED about us. It's a fantastic feeling. You will learn so much from them and from your brilliant classmates.

Probably my favorite course this semester, there was a perfect balance of intellectual stimulation and a caring for students. We read rich material but  a fair amount of reading. The TFs were amazing and Professor Ferguson is literally such a blessing as an instructor; he is so thoughtful and really cares about each student. I always felt supported throughout the class. The syllabus was flexible to the interests of the class and Prof. Ferguson and the TFs always made it known that they valued our voices as students. It was truly an amazing experience.

strengths: fascinating material, low workload, unique and creative assignments, flexibility in coursework, super accomodating policies, cool guests, makes room for personal knowledge, uses small group discussion effectively

weaknesses: very small note but i wish there was less of a discrepancy between reading material lengths from weak to weka
Professor Ferguson is the best Professor Ive had at Yale. He cares about his students as learner and people. Everything about this class is a strength.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Prof Ferguson was incredibly kind and gracious considering all circumstances
Prof. Ferguson and the TF's were so kind and understanding. They made the virtual learning experience so enjoyable

This class was probably the best class I have had yet as far as COVID-19 adaptations. Prof. Ferguson was flexible as far as assignments, deadlines and workload in order to ease the stress on us as students.
Succeeded- good integration of breakout rooms into class time, TAs did a wonderful job of guiding discussions and sharing ideas with students

virtual discussions, allowing us to engage with the class in a way that is best for us, being really flexible with grading so that we can just do the work to the best our capacity and not overwork ourselves

Honestly, being online made things less intimidating. Not that it would have ever been because the atmosphere is brilliant. But this was my first WGSS class, and I was surrounded by GENIUSES. So... I sometimes felt lost. But Professor Ferguson always guided me (and everyone else like me) into the light. Being online just made it easier for me to ask questions. But that might be a personal preference.

I liked the focus on discussion because it kept us engaged as online learners. Also the random breakout rooms during 'lecture' (though it was small enough that is felt seminar-like) allowed us to all get to know each other and bounce ideas off of different people.
This is an amazing course.

succeeded: welcome to turn our cameras off, use of breakout rooms and screen sharing

could be improved: n/a

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely!
YES YES YES. This is the best class I've taken at Yale so far. I learned so much and looked forward to logging onto Zoom every time.
Yes. 100 times out of 100. If you are interested in activism or social movements at all, this class is a necessity.

ABSOLUTELY.  This is my favorite class that I have ever taken at Yale.  I'm not a WGSS major, but this course welcomes all students with open arms.  Professor Ferguson does an absolutely wonderful job teaching, and his experiences and viewpoints really inspire his students.

100% take this class if you can get in. Dr. Ferguson is a one-in-a-million professor with incredible insight into trans and queer politics, especially as it applies to people of color. We read a plethora of papers that challenged how I view our society and revealed so many important LGBTQ+ activists and theorists. The discussions in class and in section were eye-opening and structured around participation from students.

YES YES YES. Best professor and TA's of any class I've taken at Yale. Even over Zoom, I forged fantastic connections with my peers and this class really opened my eyes to a lot of history that I was unaware of.
Yes! Highly recommend to anyone who's interested in engaging critically about queer studies.
Yes! It is a whole new world that everyone should see! This class brought up many engaging issues!

Absolutely! Everyone should take one of Prof Fergusons classes. This class was nothing like any of the classes Ive taken at Yale in the best possible way. I feel much more enriched as a result of taking the class, and it engaged me with materials and content I have never seen in academia.
Yes. I am a cis-gender, heterosexual man. Riddled with privilege and misunderstandings. I gained so so much from my peers, I cried. Take it to create an open mind. No matter who you are.

Yes this class was the favorite part of my day on many occasions. Prof. Ferguson is such an amazing professor, everything he says is like a little nugget of wisdom. Also, he is just such a cool, kind person who was willing to work with students to make the class work for them. SUCH a great experience, please take it.
Yes, take this course! It is very important content that everyone should study.
Rod Ferguson is the GOAT. Take the course!
yes!! professor ferguson is such an amazing teacher who really pushes you to interact w texts creatively.
absolutely! this was one of my favorite classes i've taken at yale. from the content to professor ferguson to the TAs, this class has been incredible. i only wish i took it sooner in my time at yale
This is the best course Ive ever taken. You learn so much in such an accepting and inviting environment. Take it!!
